newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Hungary dealers expect stable repo for 2 or 3 week.
newsitem.headline: Hungary dealers expect stable repo for 2 or 3 week.

text.p: Hungarian money market dealers expect the National Bank of Hungary (NBH) to keep the repo rate steady for at least two to three weeks, a Reuter survey of eight dealers showed on Tuesday.
The NBH's recent moves have indicated the central bank wants to keep market interest rates at the current levels in the near future, they said.
"(The NBH) seems to have decided to stabilise interest rates at the current level for a longer period," said Postabank's Karoly Barath. "I do not expect a cut in the next two or three weeks."
The NBH has cut its repo rates with almost monthly regularity in the past few months in line with a decline in inflation.
However, NBH President Gyorgy Suranyi said recently that the central bank was intent on keeping 12-month government securities yield levels at above 20 percent to protect savings.
Following Suranyi's announcement, the NBH raised the interest rate of its six-month deposit facility by 0.25 percent to 21.00 percent and introduced a 12-month deposit facility at 20.50 percent.
After the NBH moves, which hit the market by surprise, previous repo cut expectations cooled, dealers said.
Seven of the eight dealers in the survey said they did not expect a repo cut in the next two or three weeks, while the eighth dealer was uncertain.

Most dealers said the NBH was unlikely to cut its repo rates by more than 0.25 percent in the next one or two months, but a 0.25 percent cut in the one-week and one-month reverse repo rates may come, they said.
Two main economic research centres said last week that the current level of inflation was not likely to drop by the end of the third quarter of the year.

Inflation is running at 18.8 percent and the NBH expects it to be close to 17 percent in December, while a recent Reuters poll of 15 analysts showed that market expectations for December year-on-year inflation averaged 18.39 percent.
